response.answer_text: “brains create consciousness”? Look inside a living brain during an operation: what do you find? Some apparently gelatinous material, that ‘feels’ squishy? Can you see the consciousness you are looking for? If you cannot observe it, how can you apply scientific processes to discovering its nature, or its cause? Of course, there are many scientifically described processes that cannot be observed directly. But in all cases, these relate to a chain of events that are understood in behavioural terms. We speak of the ‘behaviour’ of quantum fields, etc. This behaviour is described mathematically and observed (say) as traces (behaviour) in a cloud chamber. Even ‘emergent properties’ in science are described in behavioural terms, for example phase transitions. Behaviour giving rise to behaviour is hardly surprising. Behaviour giving rise to consciousness is another matter altogether. Consciousness is required to observe behaviour. In opening up a functioning brain, can you find any colours? Or odours? Or feelings? Or flavours? Or Sounds? Or Ideas (number, form and meaning)? These qualia are the ‘objects of conscious experience’. If you cannot observe the ‘objects of conscious experience’ inside a living brain, how can you apply scientific processes to discovering their cause? How could you separate qualia from consciousness? Can a feeling can exist that is not felt? A colour that is not seen? A sound that is not heard? A flavour that is not tasted? An odour that is not smelled? Or, any idea that is not known? Of course, it is possible to imagine (say) a colour existing ‘out there’ with no one seeing it. But that is because it is imagined in ‘consciousness’. Though what about a ‘feeling’ hanging in space? Or an ‘idea’ just ‘floating around’? it is not even possible to imagine these existing independent of the capacity to feel or know. Imagine there is no consciousness at all, anywhere or anywhen… what of qualia then? No qualia, nor the awareness in which they appear, can be observed inside a living brain. All that can be observed are the qualia (perceived from the perspective of the surgeon) that appear to be the living brain of the patient. The qualia (apparent from the perspective of the surgeon) are not the ‘physical’ brain of the patient, let alone the qualia/awareness (consciousness) that is the object of study - that are believed to arise in the physical brain of the patient. Under the material model, the qualia manifesting the appearance of the patient’s brain are assumed to arise solely in the surgeon’s brain as a result of physical processes in that brain that somehow precisely mimic the appearance of the physical reality assumed to exist outside the surgeon’s brain, assumed to be caused by a long chain of assumed events. Yet, nowhere along this assumed chain of causation is there any information. It is all ’cause and effect’. Brains, like computers, comprise a set of initial conditions that are modified as a result of incoming energy flows leading to outgoing energy flows that manifest new behaviours. That is all. Only the conscious observer can infer information. Only consciousness knows ideas. Only consciousness can name objects and relations and understand meaning. Information cannot exist in the absence of meaning, and meaning cannot exist without consciousness. Where in the physical world is a single ‘idea’? If no idea exists ‘out there’, it is impossible to learn ideas from experience. Knowing ideas is inherent in consciousness, along with sensing sensations. This is not to deny the correlation between reported conscious experience and observed behaviour, including the behaviour of apparent material/energy flows in apparent brains imaged in apparent displays generated by apparent MRI machines… But correlation is not causation. As an analogy, it is possible to observe the behaviour of characters and objects in a computer game on a computer screen and deduce the rules that govern their behaviour. However, there are no ‘characters’ inside the computer, only the rules for their manifestation on the screen. In the same way, there is no need for actual objects to exist as the originals for the apparent objects manifested in consciousness. All that is required is the capacity to manifest qualia in accord with a coherent set of rules that govern their form and their behaviour. We call these rules ‘the laws of nature’ as ‘discovered’ through scientific inquiry. No observer could ever deduce the nature of the ‘hardware’ that generates the images on a computer screen from looking at the images alone. Consciousness is faced with the same impossible task: how to see beyond the qualia to the consciousness that manifests the apparent world? Brain research is great for building understanding of the correlations between reported experience and different brain states. It is futile if the quest is to understand consciousness The only ‘place’ where consciousness can be observed is from the viewpoint of the witness that is at the core of OneSelf.

Q: Is it true that consciousness that generates ideas and thoughts is an emergent property of the physical brain and therefore compatible with science? So there are really two questions here. Q1 Is it true that consciousness that generates ideas and thoughts is an emergent property of the physical brain? Q2. Is consciousness therefore compatible with science? Taking each in turn… A1. We don’t really know yet what consciousness is and I suspect that the word itself is an unhelpful way to approach mental phenomena. But from what we can tell mental phenomena are an emergent property of the brain. And we have ruled out all the other explanations. It could still be something we haven’t thought of, but it looks likely to be true. A2. I think Q2 is hinting at a problem raised by ontological dualists, which is that consciousness is an entirely different substance. And therefore if we only examine matter and energy via scientific methods we can never learn anything about consciousness. So first of all, no serious scientist or philosopher believes that ontological dualism can possibly be the case any longer. Everything is matter and energy. There is no other possibility. Secondly the dualist shares some assumptions with many scientists, which is that reductionism (accounts of reality only in terms of substances) is the only viable approach to reality. The very mention of emergent properties kicks reductionism into the long grass. The idea that reality is only found in substances is an assumption. I agree that substances are real but by any meaningful definition of “real” structures and systems are also real. Once we admit that structures and systems are also real (anti-reductionism or emergentism) then it is a relatively easy step to argue that emergent phenomena are real. And thus, yes, they are within the domain of science. And thus consciousness, or better, mental phenomena are also within the domain of science. John Searle is very good on this kind of thing, especially in his book: The Construction of Social Reality. If the subjective was not real then our present money system could not work at all, because modern money is very much part of the subjective realm. Money is money only because we think of it as money; only because we agree to act as if it does what we think it does. So having objective knowledge of a subjective domain is not a problem.

The simple answer is yes. The brain is the thing, the brain is key, the brain is the essential organ related to what we call "consciousness", i.e., your subjective conscious experience, or the "What is it like to be me?" of being you. Yes. The only complicated part of your question is the word "emerge". If you are using that word casually, then you can stop reading, because I've answered your question above, and you may not be excited about what comes next. If you are using the word "emerge" with specific intention, then read on. What's the matter with the word "emerge"? A number of smart people have debated how semantically and functionally we should regard the relationship between brain and consciousness. Does the brain "create" consciousness? Does consciousness "emerge" from the brain? In most areas of brain science (i.e., psychology, neuroscience) it is fairly commonplace to talk about the "neural correlates of consciousness" or the NCC, made very popular through this influential book by Christoph Koch: The Quest for Consciousness: A Neurobiological Approach. In these academic circles, you will find that scientists are unambiguously non-dualist--they believe in a biological explanation of consciousness. However, you will also find that it is common for these types of people to use language like "the correlates of consciousness", or "the brain circuits that cause consciousness", or "the brain generates consciousness" or "consciousness emerges from the brain"--these types of things. So if you went and asked most neurobiologists, "Does consciousness emerge from the brain?". They would answer "Yes!" and everyone would feel content. I'll tell you what's the matter with the word "emerge". However, there are other types academics who would pause if you asked them that question, and it is because of the word "emerge". These are people like the neurophilosopher Patricia Churchland (see What are the most valid criticisms of Patricia Churchlands books on neuro-philosophy?), the philosopher Daniel Dennett (see Daniel Dennett) , the consciousness studies expert Susan Blackmore (Dr. Susan Blackmore), and others. From their perspective, the problem with the standard language, e.g., the "neural correlates of consciousness" is that it suggests that there is something else besides the neural activity. Something correlated but distinct from the neural activity. When people say "brain activity generates consciousness" it implies that consciousness is something besides brain activity, that exists at a certain point in time and doesn't exist at other points in time. But what could that be? In Dan Dennett's words: Let's call the idea...Cartesian Materialism, since it's the view you arrive at when you discard Descartes's dualism but fail to discard the imagery of a central (but material) Theater where 'it all comes together.'...Cartesian materialism is the view that there is a crucial finish line or boundary somewhere in the brain, marking a place where the order of arrival equals the order of 'presentation' in experience because what happens there is what you are conscious of...We must stop thinking of the brain as if it had such a single functional summit or central point." ([1], pg 107-111) The sure sign of Cartesian materialism is anybody who tells the story of consciousness and doesn't go on to answer the 'and then what happens?' question. ([2], p. 87 ) So the idea here is that it is incorrect to talk about consciousness as if it is this "extra" thing that happens or is created by some special type of brain activity. Why are you making such a big deal about the word "emerge'? I think that this loose way of thinking about consciousness (what Dennett calls cartesian materialism) is quite prolific and gets in the way of a deep understanding the brain. I think it taints experimental designs and confuses our interpretations. I think it blocks our scientific comprehension of other cognitive processes like declarative memory, attention, vision, and decision making. I think it obfuscates attainable goals in cognitive neuroscience and blurs the data we already have. Basically, I think that Dennett, Blackmore, and the Churchlands and all those that stand with them are on to something with this consciousness philosophizing and the field of neurobiology is kind of dropping the ball on this one. Where do we go from here? Honestly, the ideas above took me a long time to wrap my head around, so don't feel too bad if you are feeling confused. If you continue down this line of thinking then that is how you get to statements like the following: "The easy way to cut through...is to draw lessons from the history of science. Electromagnetic waves don't cause light; they are light. That's what light is. Similarly with sound: a sound of middle C isn't correlated with a compression wave train of 263 Hz. It is a compression wave train with that frequency. And the feeling of warmth from a coffee cup isn't something that's correlated with mean molecular kinetic energy; it's identical with the mean molecular kinetic energy of the molecules in the cup." -Paul Churchland, [2] p. 54 "The most extreme version of this [idea] is taken by eliminative materialists, such as the Churchlands. They argue that once we understand the evolution of human behavior, skills and abilities, we will have understood everything that we need to understand. The whole idea of consciousness will just slip away, as did the idea of the "life force" or phlogiston. In other words there really is no such thing as consciousness at all." - Blackmore, [3] p. 159 "We certainly seem to be conscious, and that requires explaining, but the right kind of explanation is one that accounts for why we have this particular illusion. - Blackmore, [3] p. 218 "When we understand consciousness--when there is no more mystery--consciousness will be different, but there will still be beauty, and more room than ever for awe" -Dennett [1] p. 25 So that's the problem with the word "emerge" when you say "consciousness emerges from the brain" or whenever anyone says things like "the brain causes consciousness" or "I'm looking for the neural correlates of consciousness" or "neural patterns of activity generate consciousness". With language like that, the brain will always be misunderstood. Citations Consciousness Explained (1991) by Dan Dennett Consciousness Explained: Daniel C. Dennett:Conversations on Consciousness (2007) Ed. by Susan Blackmore Conversations on Consciousness: What the Best Minds Think about the Brain, Free Will, and What It Means to Be Human:Consciousness: An Introduction (2003) by Susan Blackmore Amazon.com: Consciousness: An Introduction (9780195153439): Susan Blackmore: Books

Does the brain create consciousness? I'm not so sure. At the very least, I know that no neuroscientist has caught the brain 'red-handed' in the act of creating consciousness. ... are we logos In neurons of the brainMaintaining voltage gradientsAcross a membrane? (That's a lyric from the new Yeasayer album.) The standard materialist position is that consciousness is tied up with the brain. There is plenty of evidence that the brain influences consciousness (and vice versa!), ranging from studies of brain damage to the well-known effects of mind-altering chemicals. The problem with going any further than this correlational fact is that no one knows how to define consciousness from an objective, third-person perspective. We only have access to one consciousness: our own. Every other consciousness is in a sense inferred from behavior. This process of inference is a social process, which is why the debate on animal consciousness is unlikely to end any time soon. We treat people as conscious because they seem conscious to us, and this seeming is a product of both our evolved perceptual systems and the cultural systems that operate on top of them. The fact that people disagree about whether a particular animal species is conscious or not suggests that there is no universal intuition about consciousness. Because the problem of consciousness is a problem of definitions, some neuroscientists have decided to stick their necks out and define it. A popular recent definition is contained in integrated information theory, proposed by Guilio Tononi and Cristoph Koch. An apparent consequence of their definition is that pretty much anything can be conscious if it has the right sort of "information integratedness". A philosopher named Eric Schwitzgebel ran with this line of thinking, and attempted to show that If Materialism Is True, the United States Is Probably Conscious.  To their credit, Tononi and Koch seem to have bitten the bullet and accepted a form of panpsychism — the idea that everything is conscious. Some philosophers dislike it when definition are too broad: they call the process "bloating". It's a useful concept in my opinion. If everything from electrons to galaxies is somewhat conscious (by virtue of being somewhere on the "information integratedness" scale) then the concept of consciousness becomes less useful as a descriptor of observable phenomena. (But then again, perhaps we never actually observe consciousness anyway. We observe with consciousness. Consciousness itself seems to have no material attributes: it is only the objects or targets of consciousness that have attributes. ) This is why it is always good to go back to the kinds of definitions of consciousness used by philosophers and mystics. These definitions are much closer to our colloquial understanding of consciousness than anything proposed by neuroscientists. Consciousness is the field of subjective experience. We can communicate aspects of this experience, but we can never share directly in any consciousness other than our own. We cannot answer the question 'What Is it Like to Be a Bat?' We can barely even speculate about it.  One of my favorite descriptions of consciousness comes from Julian Jaynes bizarre and beautiful book The Origin of Consciousness in the Breakdown of the Bicameral Mind. O WHAT A WORLD of unseen visions and heard silences, this insubstantial country of the mind! What ineffable essences, these touchless rememberings and unshowable reveries! And the privacy of it all! A secret theater of speechless monologue and prevenient counsel, an invisible mansion of all moods, musings, and mysteries, an infinite resort of disappointments and discoveries. A whole kingdom where each of us reigns reclusively alone, questioning what we will, commanding what we can. A hidden hermitage where we may study out the troubled book of what we have done and yet may do. An introcosm that is more myself than anything I can find in a mirror. This consciousness that is myself of selves, that is everything, and yet nothing at all — what is it?And where did it come from?And why? Descriptions like this also reveal why neuroscience will always struggle to study consciousness in all its private glory. How are we supposed to study something that is a "hidden hermitage"? We never actually see consciousness. All we see are its consequences in behavior. So when we look for the neural correlates of consciousness, what we are really looking for are the neural correlates of certain measurable behaviors that we think are closely related with consciousness, such as attention, self-awareness, access to information, and (perhaps most important) the ability to comprehend and communicate. If there is a type of consciousness that we are incapable of acting upon or even remembering then we will simply be unable to study it from a scientific perspective.

Neurology and psychology are both only 130 years old (with some precursors of course). The human brain is the most complicated thing in the known universe.  We can imagine a chemical reaction creating a chemical sense of "me" vs. "not-me" when an amoeba encounters things in its environment, or a light source, or a predator, or food. That doesn't tell us what it is "like" to be an amoeba. As you go up the level of complication of multi-celled organisms to ones with nervous systems, brains, etc. the level of our confusion exponentially increases as does our ignorance. We don't even know why psycho-active drugs prescribed every day for mental illness work. Differences between brains (think synesthesia, sociopathy, autism) confuse us even more.  It's like imagining that we understand quantum psychics because we know how to melt an ice cube: there is a vague connection. Very vague.  Most of what our brain does is not accessible to our conscious, and the little that is is the result of a huge number of variable working together, from DNA, every experience we have had, every sensory input we are having, to the trillions of cross-connections of our neurons. We barely have any idea what axons do or are for. There is a reason that philosophy and not science is mostly dealing with this issue: it is beyond us.

This is a very deep question that can only be answered in the context of a world-view very different from the one most people have. Most people are materialists - they believe in an objective external world of independently existing objects separate from themselves that they can passively perceive using their brains. However, serious thinkers over the last century have realized that materialism doesn't make sense. We experience interactions (photons hitting the retina etc.), not objects  - the objects are inferred from these interactions and their properties are not objectively real, they are dependent on the context and the nature of the observer. The closest we get to an objective reality is a consensus on the interpretation of an event shared by a number of observers. They can agree on a consensus to the degree to which they are the same (all humans, same brains and perceptual systems etc). This reality only extends to the group that shares the consensus, it is not objective. The features of this reality, the similar interpretations of the interactions that the group is conscious of, are conditioned by the brains of the group members. Thus the inferred contents of consciousness are dependent on the brain.  What consciousness actually is is the experience of interaction. A conscious event defines both the subject having the experience and the object that is perceived. Both of these are inferred and conditional, that is they depend on a number of factors and are not objectively real. That is why mystics say that the perceived world is not real, it is an illusion. What they mean is that our interpretation of conscious experience is not an unchanging objective reality, it is subjective. When they say things like "the world is made of consciousness" they don't mean that consciousness is a substance - there is no substance. What they mean is that our phenomenal world of objects is inferred from our experience of interations, which is what consciousness is.

response.answer_text: We can make everything simpler recognising that consciousness is defined only in relation to the environment. That it is not, by all means, a mere property of the brain.  The isolated brain Human beings may have irreversible brain dammage after only two weeks of complete isolation (just read it on the NYTimes today, don't have any reference but seems plausible). Without the possibility of exchanging information with the environment, we "lose our mind".  This because consciousness is not a mere property of the brain: it is a property of an information processor, the brain, which has the capacity –and the necessity– of seeing itself as different from other information processors (like other brains) and exchange information with them (e.g. empathise). Different level of consciousnesses Frans de Waal made clear that consciousness is not a unique property of the human brain. Chimpanzees, for instance, are perfectly aware they exist. If they have a spot on their face and they are put in front of a mirror, they clean their face. They can perfectly empathise with others: if a chimp hits another chimp, the victim might search revenge attacking a younger relative of the aggressor. They know who they are, and they know what the others might think. (De Waal, Frans. Good natured: The origins of right and wrong in humans and other animals. No. 87. Harvard University Press, 1997). So, after having said that consciousness is a property of the brain exchanging information with the environment, we can also add that the human brain has a very high level of consciousness, but it is not the only device with this property. Do ants have consciousness? Of course ants have no consciousness. In Hölldobler, B, and Edward W. The superorganism: the beauty, elegance, and strangeness of insect societies. WW Norton & Company, 2009., the authors say: "We see the insect colony as the equivalent of an organism." Ants clearly have no consciousness, but if you read the book you end up thinking that anthills do have some degree of it. Do neurons have consciousness? Following the same path, but backwards: do neurons have consciousness? Of course they don't. Only interconnected neurons, able to store information and exchange information with the environment, show different degrees of consciousness.  Consciousness as the "capacity to integrate information" Therefore, to understand human consciousness, we should maybe analyse the way the human brain processes information, which is what Giulio Tononi does in: Tononi, G. "An information integration theory of consciousness." BMC neuroscience 5.1 (2004): 42.  A bit technical (to say the least), but very interesting. One of the most valid answers I read is there –sorry for not replicating the whole article:) Regarding the unicity of human brain, I think we do have something unique. If not consciousness itself, for sure the fact that we ask ourselves what consciousness is, and why is there.

Experts disagree about whether consciousness emerges from the brain. One thing that is not controversial, however, is that in order to be conscious (in any way that we would recognize), something like a brain is required. But even though a brain is necessary for consciousness, brains and brain functions alone may not be sufficient for consciousness. That is, perhaps consciousness requires a brain and something else.  What is that "something else"? The answer to this may depend on what element of consciousness you're inquiring about. If you are interested in perception, Susan Hurley, in her book Consciousness in Action, makes a compelling case for the necessity of sensorimotor feedback loops in structuring the kind of perceptual experiences that we have. If what you're asking about is phenomenal experience (i.e., the first-person, felt experience of living, or as some philosopher's have put it, the "what it's like"), then it is highly likely that the brain alone - understood as a collection of purely physical properties - is not sufficient for consciousness. This is the mind-body problem. How can something like phenomenal experience emerge from something purely physical? How can something material cause something that is immaterial? Interestingly, this is really only an intractable problem if you assume that the brain is purely a collection of physical properties. I am not suggesting that the brain contains a spirit, or anything of that nature. What I am suggesting is that brains, skulls, your hair, your cat, your car, and the dust bunnies collecting under your bed are all what appear to be purely physical entities only through the lense of consciousness. At a subatomic level all of these things are bustling, buzzing waves of quantum fluctuation. Why are they solid at a macroscopic level? Because it is the macroscopic world that we apprehend in consciousness. These things are made material within consciousness. We then export our material experience as metaphor that we apply to physics. But all of the physical microscopic entities we are aware of are defined solely by their relational properties to our measuring devices. This means that we define these entities by what they do, not what they are. We can gather from quantum physics and theories (like string theory) that try to resolve the tension between quantum physics and general relativity, that the nature of the universe at a granular level is stranger than we can imagine. It is possible that our universe is a place where the raw field of potential consciousness is just baked into the fabric of reality. Not only is this possible, but it would go a long way toward solving all kinds of theoretical problems relating to the mind-body problem (the problem of the generation of consciousness). In such a case a brain, understood as a physical manifestation in consciousness that is representative of a deeper ontology, qualifies as a candidate for the root of consciousness. The brain that we see and measure tells only part of the story, but what we do see of it suggests that its organization may represent the configuration of the field of potential consciousness that is required for full-blown phenomenal consciousness.   But if we accept that it is the functioning organization of the brain that matters for consciousness, we really have no principled reason to draw a line around the sack of meat (the brain) and say, "some of the processes inside the meat sack are jointly sufficient for consciousness and none of the processes outside the meat sack are necessary for consciousness." That is, there may be genuine contributions from other parts of your body, or even your environment, that are also necessary processes underlying our human-style consciousness. Again, for a mind-blowing read I highly recommend Hurley's Consciousness in Action. Be warned, though, her writing is brilliant but not easy.

An example is the internal calculations and decoding that happens behind vision. What we 'see' is a highly processed version of what is actually incident on the eye - a highlight of the surfaces of the objects, depth, color, etc. The intermediate level is the one which accesses the processed information from the lower level, works on this, and interfaces with the highest level. While much of the information from the lower level is inaccessible, a fair bit is accessible. This is the generator of 'consciousness'. The highest level is the long-term memory. This is like a gist of the information processing. Some time after you finish reading this, what you retain is only the gist of the message I'm trying to convey, and your opinion about it. While you are reading, you may be aware of the structure of my sentences. You may pick up grammatical mistakes that I may have made. You might experience some emotion while you read through (for example, you may feel disgusted that you're reading a pile of BS with every sentence you proceed. Why have a distinction between lower level and intermediate level?That is, why can't access be provided to the entire information pool?Because this access has its costs. This style of processing happened to be the most efficient way to implement in humans, for the gene to carry out its end objective of replication. No. It is actually not so difficult to scientifically prove, in physics, the existence of an existing state of consciousness capable of existing independently of any material support. The so-called "Hard Problem of Consciousness" stems from the fact that we are attempting to measure consciousness with tools designed to apprehend atoms, molecules, and particles: it's much like trying to assess the dimensions of a table with a voltmeter: it does not work, and then we could say that there is a "hard problem of table dimensions" in assessing the width and length of the table. To say that the table has no length, or that independent consciousness does not exist, then becomes plain circular reasoning, as in "I have only a voltmeter, and therefore the table has no length; I have only assessment tools that pertain to matter, hence consciousness per se does not exist." It’s an error of elementary logic. As it is, it’s all rather simple. Here's what happens when you use the right tools to capture consciousness: http://philsci-archive.pitt.edu/14836/1/feels%20v999.pdf Basically, what this paper says is that an essential property of any material thing made up of material particles (to wit, the way how relevant wave functions collapse under certain circumstances, brought about by an interference event - such as measurement, observation, the establishment of new chemical bonds, etc.), is seen to not apply to consciousness - which implies that consciousness can only be a fundamental property, independent of matter and non-emergent from matter (such as that of the brain), because if it were dependent on and/or emergent from matter, the way how these wave functions collapse would inescapably carry over into how consciousness works - which it does not.

This is very much a topic of ongoing research, and while some clues have started to emerge, the big picture of how the brain does this has not yet been worked out. Piecing together the currently popular theories suggests the following general picture for how the brain creates consciousness, proceeding from the neuron to socially supported identity: neural circuits organize statistical input and output -- The brain is processing sensory input and generating motor output on a continual basis, functioning basically as a statistical information processing and prediction machine.memory constructs a dynamic model of the world -- One aspect of how the brain works is that it generates an interactive dynamic model of the world based on the statistical information received from the senses. This model includes an understanding of the environment, a representation of the physical body itself (body image; the way you know your hand is yours and not somebody else's), a representation of other beings in the social world (parents, friends, society, animals), and ultimately a representation of oneself. The representation of oneself may be an extension of social modeling reflected back onto oneself (the purported owner of one's perceptual experiences); it may also be the "actor" responsible for the observed behavior represented by the body image (perception of "agency").information integration unifies coherent perception -- One aspect of the "conscious field" is that it appears unified, complete, coherent, and self-aware, even though experiments show it is not. This may be made possible by extensive feedback pathways within the brain which exchange information between brain areas, unify perception into a single coherent point of view, and drive the brain's representation of the body's identity toward a consistent model of goal-directed voluntary action.episodic memory creates identity through personal narrative -- In humans in particular, "one-shot memory" is able to store an episodic record of the events we experience along with causal models and explanations. This "episodic memory" is organized into a multi-layer narrative on many time scales. Our knowledge of our own personal history forms our identity of who we are, which further supports our understanding of that entity which is being aware, experiencing perceptions, and causing actions.... our "self".social structure reinforces a model of reality and agency -- Society and human culture further reinforce this "mutually developed" model of who we are, who other people are, who they think we are, what we think they think of us, etc.. There are many levels of recurrent nesting of representations of our personal and social identities, both within our own brain and distributed across the brains of our family, community, and social relations.language codifies social reality and supports transmission of cultural beliefs -- All of this is brought into a crisp structured social-conceptual framework using language. Language is a culturally-transmitted conceptual system with a spontaneously developed sequential coding scheme (words and grammar). Language allows society to operate within a common believe system that is kept synchronized across individuals. This belief system includes concepts such as personal responsibility, intentional action, truth, knowledge, and other core belief frameworks that provide a foundation to our conscious experience.Thus the brain plays a role in generating and maintaining a model of the world that includes "us," and also includes "us" believing we are having self-aware experiences. In modern human society, this is further supported by a shared reality and belief system that we acquire from infancy through cultural transmission, human language, episodic memory, and personal identity. First are mental states reducible in some way to physical states or are they wholly different? If they are reducible, then you have your answer in physical necessity. That is very surprising. Conscious experience seems wholly different from physical facts. If I know that such and such atom will collide with some other atom, why should that be the same thing as some mental state (I.e. feeling hungry or happy)? In this case the story about the masses and positions and charges, etc. of the particles was all along the same thing as my conscious experience of hunger… Of course we could adopt some other physical reduction, by way of behavior or function for examples, but these seem just as absurd if not more so. Again this makes no sense as conscious experiences may serve functions, but they are not merely funttions… Such views seem to merely mistake our mental states for some physical state. But what if they are not reducible? Well then we should ask whether the mental facts can influence the physical facts. If they cannot, then we might wonder why the experience of eating a cheeseburger is associated with the cheeseburgers being eaten, rather than some other experience such as a paralyzing fear, or a splash of yellow, or an interest in the flight patterns of geese. We seem to be driven toward the view called epiphenominalism, which is not reassuring precisely because our phenomenological experiences have no power to accomplish anything. it would be just as plausible for my mind to be overcome with a desire to swim the English Channel every time my body needed food, as my desiring the swim will accomplish nothing more or less than my hunger. Yet if the mental facts can alter the physical facts, then it seems the causal closure of the physical is in trouble (as Jaegwon Kim has argued). Ultimately if the brain does generate consciousness then how this is done is a huge mystery. In my opinion the brain is not the right kind of thing to generate consciousness, however…

There are many versions of dualism but the main essence of all of them  is presence of two separate entities to constitute consciousness. One  entity being physical, dependent on the brain anatomy, condition; other  entity being the non-materialistic entity which is our self-being. Now, with time and advancement in technology, people could detect the neuronal signals. Scientists discovered the different areas of the brain performing different functions like language, emotions, humor etc. So, they started moving from dualism to materialistic view of consciousness i.e. neurons and their billions of connections make our consciousness. However, no such specific area of brain has been identified as site of consciousness (as in case of vision, motor actions etc). The reason being, consciousness is much more complex than humor, emotions, language etc which are only a small part of it. And then there are the findings such as this: Brijesh Chandrakar's answer to What happens to human consciousness after death? Ian Stevenson andJim B. Tucker studied Reincarnation!!!  They investigated claims made by   children, usually between the ages of 2 and 6 years old, who say  they've  had past lives.The children are sometimes able to provide  enough detail  about those lives that their stories can be traced back  to an actual  person—rarely famous and often entirely unknown to the  family—who died  years before. These cases are rare but not unique.  Tucker has studied 2500 cases. The results suggested that consciousness can survive death and can even continue to other brain, or re-incarnate in layman terms. Now, these cases are extremely rare, and there are anomalies many times. So, the hypothesis can't be tested in fully scientific way. If this has to be true, then consciousness can be independent of brain i.e. it doesn't  emerge from brain. But neither these studies are strong enough to prove this argument nor our understanding of brain anatomy and functions sound enough to pin point the site of emergence of consiousness in brain. Hence, the answer from my side is we don't know yet.

The current scientific approach is to narrow the meaning of the word ‘consciousness’. In that way of using the word, ‘consciousness’ is not a separate thing. It is just just something that happens in the brain. Then it is very easy to explain because there is really nothing to explain. For that reason, I am not a big fan of the word ‘consciousness’ or certainly not how the word is being used more frequently by many ‘experts’. Instead, let us use the word “Life”. How does the brain make us alive? How does the brain produce Life? Well, the brain does not produce Life. Many animals and organisms are alive that don’t have brains. So clearly Life is not produced by the brain. Life was around a long time before brains came along. Bacteria are alive but don’t have brains. The same is true for ears of corn, wheat, rose bushes, and most of the cells in our bodies. Our cells are alive but what makes them alive is not the brain. So what is Life? How does Life begin? These are fair questions, important questions that have been asked for thousands of years. The “Scientific” approach is really a Materialistic approach. One which approaches the problem by saying “What can we observe in the laboratory?” And the answer is “We’re not really sure”. Just about every Scientific paper in the area of neuroscience ends with a statement similar to “More research is needed in this area”. This a built in advertisement for the need for more funding without actually coming out and saying “We thought we might be able to figure this one small part of consciousness out but we found some interesting things - although not what we were looking for - and we really found more unanswered questions than we started with”. So what are some of the new questions about consciousness that have come up? Here are a few: 99% of the wiring in the brain is within specific regions of the brain and yet the main feature of the brain is that the parts work together as a unified whole. Different parts of the brain operate at different rates but yet are able to work together - usually seamlessly - to produce a comprehensive picture of the world with us moving through that world. How do the different parts work together when they work at different speeds? Why does our unconscious seem smarter than our conscious mind? When we have a problem that we can’t solve, why is it best to get away from the problem or “sleep on it”? The answer will often come at an odd time or while we are asleep and not even thinking about the problem. Many areas of research start out with initial optimism but run into confusing obstacles. Creating an artificial eye is a good example. There was initial optimism then some obstacles came up - the physical size of the electrodes connecting the chip to the visual cortex, and the problem of the neural code not being understood. The problem of the neural code was overcome by recording code from the retina and that seemed to be close enough - the brain could adapt to that prerecorded code and adjust to it. But then a bigger obstacle was run up against. Not even sure what the obstacle is. A solution that was ‘just around the corner’ is still just around the corner. So what is the hold up? We’re not sure so more research is needed in this area. Much has been learned but often not answers to the original questions. The firing of neurons seems to map quite nicely into 10 dimensions. Why? That is a good question. Researchers trying to unravel the mysteries of consciousness usually quietly move on to move practical areas of research involving cell types, genetic coding and figuring out what causes various diseases. What can we learn from what is going on? Science is not Philosophy. Science is a useful tool. But Science is very Materialist. The current approach is to see consciousness as being something produced by the physical brain. But there is a big, big problem with that. What if there is more to consciousness than what goes on in the physical brain? The physical universe is a very small part of all there is. But it’s all we can study in a lab. The problem is when what can be studied in a lab tries to become a comprehensive way of looking at the world. Science is a tool. There are many questions Science cannot answer. There are many questions Science frowns upon being asked.

Here is a materialist answer to the question: Does consciousness emerge from brain? The currency of thought, conscious and unconscious, is the pattern of nerve impulses flowing around in multiple, distributed circuits. The unconscious mind surely operates on these circuit impulse patterns (CIPs). Now, what is different about conscious mind? It thinks about the same things as does unconscious mind, only does so more explicitly. That is, conscious mind knows what it knows, feels what it feels, orchestrates its desires, and so on. The parsimonious explanation is that conscious mind must also be using CIPs, and that allows conscious mind to interact with the rest of the brain to adjust attitudes and behavior. Conscious mind has very low “carrying capacity,” as in working memory (Example, how many digits can you hold in your mind at any one time?). This suggests that consciousness, once it “emerges” soaks up a lot of neural circuitry that is processing whatever is being attended. Recent evidence indicates that consciousness mechanisms might act like a movie, streaming in frames of successive working memory contents, each snippet being held in a circuit buffer prior to being read out. The strongest correlate of conscious thought is synchrony in multiple field-potential bands among CIPs located in different parts of cortex. It thus is possible that is synchrony that allows consciousness to emerge. A common mistake, I think, is to confuse wakefulness with consciousness. All species shows signs of wakefulness when they are out about doing things in their world. There is no sign that the vast majority have consciousness as humans do. In humans, we can be awake, but only consciousness of what the mind is attending to at any one moment. See more at my book, Mental Biology (Prometheus)

Going by our best current understanding, we must assume that consciousness is indeed an emergent feature of processing an environment while planning ahead and drawing from experience. Understanding multiple entities and instances of similar objects is a necessary feature in order to navigate complex environments with repetitive patterns. As such, the object-oriented perception we, and to a degree some other animals, employ, necessitates a ‘self’ object, as well as a clear differentiation between the self and other instances of the same kind of object, such as other people. In a social setting, the skill to differentiate and track individuals, rather than treat each individual as the same group-identity, is critical to successful cooperation, hence the ability to recognize individuals of a social group in social animals - evolutionary pressure brings out those things. “brings out” is another way to say “it lets them emerge”. So, again, to the best of our knowledge, consciousness is an emergent consequence of the way we process our environment, and that processing happens in the brain. So, yes, consciousness does emerge from the brain.

People are a bit vague when they use the word consciousness.  It can mean different things. So let's start with awareness.  Awareness is that ability to perceive the environment and act appropriately.  A significant chunk of the brains of humans and animals is dedicated to performing that activity. It works by computation.  Sensory data is collected as a torrent-like stream of information.  From this stream, the brain/mind builds an ongoing hypothesis, which solves the following problem: "What the heck is happening?". This process is not mysterious or unknown. It's stuff that researchers mostly understand.  It involves a bunch of recognition activities. And these coalesce to form a panoramic world model. Robotic systems can replicate this activity, and this is why we see self-driving cars that can react to changing conditions, avoid sudden obstacles and so on. Artificial vision, artificial sensors, can all be rigged up, have their outputs shoved into computers, and then the computers can attempt to agree upon a usable model of the world. Awareness stems from this ability to build a live real-time model of the world from all this noisy sensory data.  And so equipped, the organism can take action which makes sense in the context. In a simple organism, this is all about working out where the ground is, where the food is, where danger lurks. In a self driving car, it's all about where the edges of the road are, what is a drivable surface?, are there obstacles?. In more sophisticated organisms this awareness is extended to unseen things, and things that might happen. Stuff that is inferred from available clues, and recognised patterns.  The more sophisticated the awareness, the more the organism can predict and shape future events. When the internal model can answer the question "what would happen if this happened" - it opens the door to shaping the environment. In my view, human consciousness is simply common-or-garden awareness, running at a very high level, with a few additional power "apps". One of these apps is the ability to aggregate a complex idea behind a simpler representation. This acts as a mental lever, and lets us internally manipulate arbitrarily complex notions, with hierarchies of these aggregations. Another ability is to associate these aggregations with different symbols. We can associate a notion with a particular sounds or shape.    This ability allows us to do reading, writing, mathematics, talking and listening.  We can make an utterance which takes a bunch of ideas turns it into sound-symbols, which are then reconstructed by the listener. We can write out an idea, and it can be read by others many years later. This single app transformed the human experience.  And gave rise to language,  culture, technology and so on. This attribute is the biggest difference between mere awareness and what we tend to call human consciousness. One talent we have is the trivial ability to rehearse a sentence before we utter it. We can say something silently, and "hear it".  This leads to the inner voice. It is a way to talk to ourselves. This is not consciousness. But a lot of people seem to think it is. I don't accept that consciousness is fundamentally mysterious or spooky. There certainly remain some unanswered difficult questions. But in essence we can see that using a network of interconnected cell-sized processors, we can do the sort of computation required to do awareness and do the other stuff.

In my view, to ask how the brain creates consciousness is like asking how an abacus creates math. The brain has its own context which has little to do with us. We use the brain, and our awareness is limited and shaped by its function, but there is no reason to suppose that any part of the brain even knows that we exist. Many have understood that there is a problem with connecting the activities of neurons or molecules with direct experiences such as colors and flavors. I grew up with a materialistic view and was unaware that there were other possibilities, except for religious views. I did not know that many philosophers throughout history had intelligent arguments which brought materialism into doubt, but eventually I began to develop questions about materialism on my own. The most problematic issue in my mind was why something like a brain or a body should feel anything at all, when all of its functions can be explained without any such feelings. Without knowing it, I had stumbled upon what David Chalmers famously called "The Hard Problem" of consciousness. Since that time, I have put together a synthesis of ideas from many different disciplines to come up with a solution that I think might be crazy enough to be on the right track. If I'm right, the brain does not create consciousness, nor do cells or molecules, but rather consciousness or sense is the fundamental condition of all possible existence (including physical objects, information, and subjectivity).  Consciousness is not like other things. To study it we must 'break the fourth wall' so that our own direct experience is featured in that experience's model of itself. It turns out that this is a trick that not everyone can do. How does the brain create consciousness? Late to the party, as always, I’ve started and paused this answer a dozen times. Not simply because there are some excellent answers already, which there are, or even because of my general acceptance that we simply don’t yet know. Rather, I’m not even sure what consciousness is, or even if it exists. OK, I’m sure I’m conscious right now. Something individual, self-reflective and dare I say analytical is going on. But what if we have invented it, to explain, describe or rationalize the “inner workings” we feel underpin our own behaviours? We then describe the “systems” of memory, attention and processing logically required to support our contention. It’s possible. But is it a thing? Does it have mass? Can it be measured, or even clearly and unarguably defined? Perhaps, but perhaps not at our current levels of technological sophistication and instrument resolution. Let’s assume it exists, anyway. Perhaps it’s simply a useful virtualisation or ‘working model’ that the brain synthesizes to assist us with placing ourselves within our world. That seems likely, to me anyway. I know this isn’t really helping, but it’s helping me preface my ramblings. Perhaps we should also ask, how did we get here? I briefly wrote about the evolution of our mammalian ancestors and the seemingly important divergence away from olfactory dominance (to a visual-auditory dominance) on our branch of the family tree in my answer to What is the most sophisticated form of communication that we see in other life forms?. It may provide a clue to how we leveraged some ‘abandoned’ wiring as it were to do ‘new stuff’, or to do old stuff differently. An earlier example, much earlier, as in way back when mammals invaded the niches left by dinosaurs after their overwhelming if partial demise 65 million years ago, may be when ‘we’ (in a very vague mammalian sense) expanded beyond our previously nocturnal habits yet retained and possibly re-purposed some of our enhanced night-vision processing capability (which evolved from hiding from those dinosaurs) to do neat things like ‘emotions’. It made a good fit with placental behaviour, anyway. Which is to say that to my mind ‘successful adaptation’ seems a likely “reason for being’ here. ‘Higher’ forms of consciousness arose from such successive, incremental changes. More so than simply being a property that serendipitously emerges from a gathering complexity of suitably self-referential and highly integrated connections, feeding forwards and backwards, persisting just so and attaining some temporal phase alignment or resonance. That may well be true, at least in part, but it’s a sign also of many underlying, incremental changes: smaller, successful adaptations that build up into what we much later have labeled a “system”, or even a collaboration of systems. Enhanced consciousness was thus selected for its survival value. How we view such things depends upon dimensions of breadth, depth and scale. I won’t use the words ‘wholistic view’, tempted as I may be, but I acknowledge that we exist as a ‘whole thing’ operating as an agent in a survival context. Whatever it is, and however it arrived, we seem to possess it (consciousness, I mean). It probably exists on a sliding scale of sorts, a continuum that may well yet reach beyond our own modern human experience. You can obviously ascribe varying levels of conscious perception and awareness to other animals, and our very much shared origins would suggest that it’s only by degree that some ‘luxury options’ are deleted as we move further away from our own ‘lofty’ position of self-appointed ‘deepest thinker’. We can’t be absolutely certain what a bare-bones consciousness-enabled brain looks like neurologically, either in a gross regionalized morphological or neuron-specific sense (Pyramidal cell, anyone?). Many of the mammalian brain’s feature set has correspondences right down to insect level. Whilst they may operate and behave in a far more reactive way than our more contemplative selves, they get around quite successfully without the bells and whistles. Perhaps ‘insect consciousness’ is a thing? I wrote about insect cognition and neurology in my answer to How do insects store memory? But back to the question. Koch, Tononi and others (I’m simply too lazy to name them, sorry, but there’s a link below) have recently suggested that “the anatomical neural correlates of consciousness are primarily localized to a posterior cortical hot zone that includes sensory areas, rather than to a fronto-parietal network involved in task monitoring and reporting”. So is it all a matter of sufficient complexity, connectivity and timing in the sensory pathways? Perhaps. It’s an idea that appeals to me, anyway, more so than systems of focus and attention, important though they may be. I’m not always focused or attentive, yet I remain vaguely conscious of what is happening. And what happens when I am immersed in thought, dreaming, unconscious or even sub-conscious seems mysteriously disconnected from clear explanation. Getting the timing right does seem critical. Holding onto a target just long enough to make relevant connections without becoming overburdened with data, yet not so quickly that the “image” is too faint, or merely lost in the background. An integrating orchestrator or “theatre” would be helpful here and the claustrum is just one such target for investigation (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1569501/). But the overall consciousness “system”, if that’s what it is, is far more complicated than “just one thing” or even a bunch of “things”. Integration is clearly important, but neural plasticity may well play a role, too. As may the effect of Degeneracy and complexity in biological systems. (Degeneracy? That sounds wrong to me, too. It’s about time those degenerate neurons grew up!) It seems likely that sharing and storing memory data along multiple, interconnected paths, in a sense averaging out many near-identical ‘copies’ of our perceptual experiences helps us to retrieve and select data quickly and ‘accurately’ upon demand and over time. It’s all back to timing. I wrote at length about consciousness, timing, electrical coupling vs glutamatergic transmission and the balance between metabotropic and ionotropic receptors (which alters significantly by the way when you compare and contrast the evolution of sauropsids and mammals) in my answer to How are the many ways electrical activity in the brain and consciousness related? It’s not just about whats ‘under the hood’, either. It’s also about how the ‘wetware’ is used. Language is implicated in all of this, if only because it has been pivotal in modern human development. Symbolic, representational language makes consciousness somehow richer and more useful to us. Such sophistication may however work against us here, in that we tend to over-emphasize ourselves and our capabilities and forget that less complex animals with seemingly very basic communication methods are ‘aware’ of us, too, and to varying degrees aware of ‘themselves’ and their ‘place’ in their own social context. Which takes us back to that continuum. We should also be mindful that human social and technological development generally is also intimately associated with what we today perceive as consciousness. Just to illustrate this, consider that spoken language as we use it today may go back only 70,000 years or so; written, symbolic representation much less again. Early stone tools date to around 2.5 million years ago, but truly sophisticated tool use and manufacture may only date back 300,000 years or less. Whatever the age, it takes a personal focus and broadly communicative social “memory” to make a useful tool and to “pass it on”. It’s a conscious act. Yet we are not alone in this, then or now. More likely to distinguish modern humanity from other species, ritual burial first occurred perhaps just 130,000 years before the present. Covering a body in ochre, burning and burying it with artifacts certainly puts a definitive stamp of “higher consciousness” upon this time or shortly thereafter (there are disputes over dating). All of which prompts the thought, how did our ancestors “think” and perceive of their world before developing the skills and technologies we take for granted today? And what implications does that have for the brain-based “systems” we assume shape our consciousness? Knowing that the wetware was the same - or similar - probably matters, but we can only infer the programming from a scant fossil record. Behaviours don’t fossilize well. Again I investigated the genetic origins that may underpin some of these developments, including language itself. It’s worth noting that much like the emergence of consciousness itself, specific genetic changes are usually subtle enablers that work in concert with many other genes to produce a measurable variance. Anyway, I wrote about this in my answer to Is there any evidence from what we know about languages and linguistics that suggests that the human brain has changed somewhat significantly in the last 5,000 years? (The answer was no, by the way.) In any case I’m pretty sure I’m conscious right now, but how much of that reflection upon my personal self-awareness is because I’ve been taught to think like that? Which is to say, is human consciousness as much a cultural meme, added to, analysed and passed along for thousands of years, as it is physical manifestation of underlying neurology and genetics? My personal theory is as follows (albeit non-academic it explains a lot of observations): Our brain is basically this set of routines that try to make sense of what they observe. The inputs for these observations are obviously what they receive from the external senses, but also from internal senses, a.k.a. from introspection. The (set of routines that is the) brain can observe itself, and tries to make sense of what it thus observes. Note though, that it cannot see all (introspection is limited) and that it can only interpret what it sees, just like it can only interpret what it sees with the external senses. (Even though the brain is the only observer of itself, it is after all only an observer, so its interpretation of what it sees can be flawed.) This observation of self is what consciousness is. Note that the brain observes *itself*, so consciousness is not something that is external to the brain (no homunculus that is in control) and neither do you actually need consciousness to operate. That’s why animals can exhibit higher-level mental processes without necessarily being conscious.. That’s why you can drive home while immersed in thought without actually realizing that you are driving and without realizing where you are driving. There are a lot of things you can do on automatic pilot, because that’s what your brain does, it’s not what your consciousness does. Consciousness only adds to the brain the awareness of what it is doing, but it is not needed. And as we can see from animals, consciousness — or the ability to observe inner processes — is a matter of degree. Some animals have it less, others have it more, humans have it a lot more.. (I suppose once you surpass a certain threshold, a positive feedback loop is created, which is responsible of the exponential evolution of our knowledge..) Heard of these tests where they determined that the electrical impulses linked to a decision actually happen some small amount of time before the mind actually thinks it decides..? From which the researchers conclude that we don’t have free will because the brain already fires before the mind decides..? What actually happens is that the brain does decide, which fires the electrical impulses, which triggers the observation of these, which is fed back to the brain which after all is observing itself, which triggers the interpretation that a decision was taken.. So, it is not the decision that comes after the electrical firing, but it is the observation that a decision was taken that comes later. There is also no such thing as the conscious mind and the sub-conscious mind as two separate ‘areas’ of the brain. What happens is that introspection only can see so much of the inner processes. So, there’s only one mind, which can observe itself, but only in a limited way.. That gives the false perception that there is some unconscious mind at work that we the conscious mind cannot see. However, whatever it is that is happening in the mind that we cannot see is still us observing and reasoning about the world. We just don’t have the full view on how we come to conclusions.. But whatever ‘we’ is, it is the whole brain.. One conclusion that I draw from all this is this: it is impossible to ‘know’ yourself… your image of self is only a flawed interpretation of a limited observation..

Most neurologists believe the answer is yes. However no one knows exactly how this happens. There is nothing in our laws of physics and chemistry that remotely suggests how or why collections of non-conscious particles become conscious. Hence we have the hard problem of consciousness. Most philosophers of mind concede we have made little (if any) progress in understanding how consciousness emerges from matter (or our brain). Alternatively, consciousness may in some sense be fundamental. There are a number of ways this could be. One is that matter is dual aspect: it has both physical and mental qualities. Then the problem of how our consciousness emerges is how collections of particles (that possess some rudimentary degree of consciousness) combine to create the kinds of experiences we have. However, this “combination” problem is also extremely daunting. Another possibility is that mind and matter are fundamentally different things (dualism). But the problem here is how two fundamentally different substances can interact. Idealism proposes that everything is fundamentally mind. However this view also has its critics. Bertrand Russell proposed neutral monism. Here mind and matter are two aspects of a more fundamental (neutral) reality. Perhaps using such a framework we might posit that the brain filters out the aspect of consciousness awareness that we experience (while other living creatures filter a different kind of experience, based on their particular biology). Obviously, this is another controversial move for many.

It is definitely true that the brain is, in some way, involved in the process consciousness. Damage the brain and consciousness is compromised. Stimulate the brain and new objects appear in consciousness (phosphenes, faces, sounds, memories etc). The reverse is also true. A particular state of consciousness, such as remembering someone’s face, will have clear neural signatures appear in the brain’s face area (known the fusiform face area). These location and pattern of activity will be correlated with the conscious process at play. However, does this imply that consciousness is confined to the brain and/or produced by the brain? No, it doesn’t. Let’s try to understand this with a simple analogy: a smartphone. Because it is fashionable these days to talk about the brain in terms of computing analogies, this is an effective analogy. When you wish to watch a news video on your smartphone, such as CNN (hopefully not Fox News), you open your browser and enter the url to stream the video, and the video-stream is displayed on the screen. If you had a way to monitor the electrical activity in the circuitry of the phone, you’d see the specific patterns underlying the processing and streaming of the video. Moreover, if you damage the circuitry, the video-streaming will be disrupted. Does this mean that the the CNN video is created by the phone? Surely not. The CNN signals are distributed across space, at least the the proximity of a base station. The smart-phone is merely a receiving device that is able to process the signal and display it on the screen. The electrical activity patterns are highly correlated with the scenes being displayed. But correlation, as we all know, is NOT causation. Could consciousness operate according to similar principles? Although the physical basis of conscious phenomena is not well understood (actually, far from well-understood, despite several theoretical attempts), and how the neural circuitry of the brain is able to interact with it remains a complete mystery, the evidence is quite strong that consciousness does not emerge from brain activity. This is a materialistic assumption and has no basis in facts or experiment.

David F. Prenatt Jr.'s answer to Is the brain the receiver of mind and consciousness, or their generator? As pointed out by many other posters, it is an open question as to whether the brain generates consciousness, or simply receives it.  It has been an open question since René Descartes first posited cogito ergo sum, or, "I think, therefore I am."  As far as I know, no scientist has come up with any testable hypothesis with regard to essence or existence, although existentialist philosophers and epistemologists sure like to debate these sorts of questions. How do the legs create walking? The brain does not " create" consciousness anymore than the legs " create" walking. A real question would be , what are the neural correlates for specific conscious experiences? Once neuroscience can specify these then nothing further is required. Just as life requires no more explanation that a detailed biochemical description of the processes involved so consciousness needs no more explanation than a neurological description of the processes involved. Just as the search for the "life force" ,which was thought to imbibe inert matter with life was futile and incoherent, so is the search for a " special" explanation of consciousness over and above a detailed description of the neural activity involved. What " special" explanation would satisfy those who require it? Certainly not a scientific one, it would have to satisfy a need to be accepted. A blob has a light sensitive patch connected to a few internal neurons, a light shines on the patch and the neurons fire in a certain way, the blob is aware or "conscious " of the light. Roll forward a few million years, light shines on the eye and we are visually conscious of, say, a tree. Where is the mystery? Complicated surely, and not yet fully specified by neuroscience. But why the need for consciousness dust? Why the need for the God of the synaptic cleft? The consciousness of, say, a tree is not "created" by neural activity, it is the neural activity. No special explanatory woo- woo is needed, no creation of some mysterious consciousness substance . Alternatively you can, if you are of a metaphysical bent, invent dualism , stipulate that mind and matter as two seperate " stuffs", and then futilely search for the answer to the self- created inexplicable pseudo- problem of the interaction between mind and matter.

WARNING: technical discussion follows I’ve arrived at the following conclusion: A pain as one usually conceives of a pain, in mentalistic terms, is that which appears as the (so-called) neural correlate on the screen of a brain monitor. To be sure, this is a somewhat peculiar factor, that which appears as the neural correlate. Here is my explanation: The nervous system of the individual in question, call him Smart (after J.J.C.), does not subject the neural correlate, a neural event that occurs in his brain, to perceptual processing of any sort, and hence Smart does not perceive it in any way. To put it the other way around, the neural correlate does not appear to him in any way. Nevertheless, he does pick up on it through neural pathways in his brain—that is, if he picks up on it at all, for he might not. It is plausible to conjecture that he picks up on it even though he does not perceive it, since it occurs right there in his brain as a natural operation of the brain. For the sake of an expression, I say that Smart registers the neural correlate. Registration, then, is not a form of perception, in that it does not involve perceptual processing of any sort, but it does yield awareness of the neural correlate. How does Smart conceive of the neural correlate, then? He does not perceive it in any way, and hence he does not conceive of it as a neural event, even though that is what it is. Since he does not perceive it, but does register it, it stands to reason that he registers that which lies at the first step of the perceptual process when the perceptual process does run its course. Unfortunately, English does not afford any graceful way to say this, but the perceptual process begins with X, the material on which it works, if you will, and Smart registers X. But X is that which appears as the neural correlate when the neural correlate does appear. That which Smart registers, then, is that which appears as the neural correlate. It appears on the screen of a brain monitor when it does appear, since, as it happens, there is no other way to capture an image of it. To answer the question, then, Smart conceives of the neural correlate as a pain, since he has learned to call events like that pains. That which appears as the neural correlate, however, is of course numerically identical to the neural correlate, and it appears as a neural event because that is what it is. The so-called neural correlate, then, is not a correlate at all. It is the pain as the pain appears, and that is to say, it is simply the pain. Nothing occurs but that neural event. Generalizing from this case, if that is permissible, it follows that consciousness is a purely physical phenomenon that can be understood only in physical terms, and that to understand it thoroughly in those terms is to understand it without remainder. The brain, then, generates consciousness in that it generates the neural activity that constitutes consciousness, and there is no suggestion here that anything else occurs, besides that neural activity. None of this has anything to do with emergentism. *** *** *** Ryan Fox Squire (or another specialist), Granted that the neurological details are missing, why doesn’t this work?
